pros: Great work environment High-level networking opportunities
cons: No work-life balance Lack of internal coordination

pros: Everyone knows the AC. It's the place to be for emerging thought leaders, and the place to retire. Company is growing lots.
cons: Lots of white men in Sr positions, including for regional centers. Few women, fewer POC.

review_title: Great Place to start a Career
pros: Incredible team of people That are supportive.
cons: Long hours and often working after COB

pros: information, career, development, opportunity, networking
cons: low pay, intensive, stressful, Inetse, stress, long hours

pros: Good environment, culture, people, work, etc.
cons: nothing at all, great great

job_title: Young Global Professional in Washington, DC
pros: Interesting work. Fun to be fly on the wall.
cons: Lots of admin, limited research assitance.

pros: Good people, smart intellectual environment, decent connections
cons: Unorganized work environment at times

review_title: Not worth it —if you're talented enough to work here you can do much better!
pros: Most junior staff at AC are great, depending on the program the work can be really interesting, it's a well-known DC think tank that will provide you with the experience needed to jumpstart a career in policy (a decent place to intern at)
cons: For the most part, AC program directors have terrible management skills which leads to programs being run nearly entirely by junior staff, there is widespread nepotism and discrimination in the workplace, and office politics at AC can make the work very stressful, multiple programs are on the midst of collapsing due to the insane turnover rate among junior staff, and organization leadership is completely out of touch with the needs of junior staff — you will be overworked to the bone for extremely low pay, even compared to other think tanks. Are you ok with undervaluing yourself in this way? There are plenty of similar opportunities available in DC where the work culture is much better than at AC, and the mass exodus of employees in the past few months highlights this. A lot of the positive reviews on here seem to have been written by interns — the experience at AC for an intern is markedly different for an intern than that of junior staff that actually have to deal with management on a day-to-day basis.

review_title: Great people, good mission, decent work life balance
pros:
Great people dedicated to furthering the transatlantic relationship. 
The mission is good but is getting muddled in some regards.
cons:
The work can be overwhelming and hectic more than it should be.
Lack of centralization leads to vastly different experiences among teams.

review_title: Ok work environment / very flexible / not great upward mobility
pros:
Very flexible (although depends on the center)
Interesting topics 
Fun work colleagues 
Great office space downtown dc
cons:
Lots of infighting between centers
Huge age gap between junior and senior employees 
Can become toxic 
Can have crazy work hours depending on center

review_title: Great place to start your career
pros: Exposure and opportunities. Great expertise and people
cons: No work life balance and understaffed

pros:
-Flexibility
-Good team spirit 
-Immense exposure to important issues and people
cons:
-relatively low salary
-poor work culture surrounding events (junior employees are expected to pull all nighters and subsequently fight to be paid either in compensation or through comp time)

pros: Learn a lot about think tank world. Meet many good, young people who are ready to change the world. Good place to have experience and to start out.
cons: less pay and not a lot of promotion.

review_title: A great think tank to work inn
pros: Great working environment in this company
cons: They could be paying a little better

review_title: Good especially for networking although underpaid
pros: Good especially for networking and some good benefits
cons: Underpaid and overworked and can be too competitive

review_title: This isn't the non-profit job you've been looking for
pros: Your fellow junior staffers are a hard-working bunch of people with incredible knowledge in their fields and wonderful ideas. You will have amazing conversations with the people around you and learn a lot.
cons:
If this is your first foray into the nonprofit space and you come in hoping to do some good for the world, you might as well shelve those aspirations from day 1. The Atlantic Council's mission of "shaping the global future together" is purposefully abstract. The Council cares much more about doing what's important as opposed to doing what's right. Their policy of intellectual independence is a joke and your list of donors will determine what you can and can't work on.

With regards to the staff, while the junior staff are lovely well-intentioned people, I have never seen senior leadership more out-of-touch with their own organization. The pay gap is enormous and it's reflected in the way junior staff are treated. 

Finally, if you are a person of color, avoid this place like the plague. Seriously, don't do it. The amount of racially coded language that was thrown my way by senior staff was genuinely shocking.

job_title: Associate Director, Communications in Washington, DC
pros: Well-known company, learn a lot
cons: overworked, underpaid... amazes me how little junior staff who work very hard for the company make

review_title: A good place to begin your career in DC
pros:
International Work Environment 
Opportunity to Grow
Networking with people to support your career
Learning on the job 
Good colleagues
cons: Work-life balance proved difficulty to establish

review_title: Good work experience but long hours
pros:

-publishing opportunities

job_title: Assistant Director, Communications in Washington, DC
pros: Learn a lot, great coworkers, well-known organization
cons: Junior staff is overworked and underpaid

pros: Talented colleagues, fun work environment
cons: Long hours, low pay, high turnover

pros: Busy, busy but supportive leadership and collaborative attitudes
cons: There can be turnover often

review_title: Great place, must be willing to work hard and take initiative
pros: Lots of opportunity. A great platform.
cons: Not a typically think tank, need to be prepared to seek out opportunities and work hard.

pros: Experience with writing and research. Independence to work on personal projects. Trusted with important materials and events. Learned administrative skills.
cons: Not enough to do during less busy periods, and too much to do doing busy periods. No intern interaction with those outside of your team. Competitive work environment. Lacks diversity.

pros: Interesting content. Passionate and hardworking team in some departments and cool speakers.
cons: Poor leadership and oversight. No real investment in the team itself.

pros: Many projects and interesting opportunities
cons: Low pay, often very long hours

pros: Potential travel experiences (but very limited at the junior staff level)
cons:
Closed minded management, pay below industry average, horrible work-life balance, poor collegial culture

*if you're smart enough work get a job here, you're more than qualified to find a better experience somewhere else. Avoid at all costs

pros: Smart place to start your career
cons: Too self absorbed and works its young employees to the bone for very little pay

review_title: Great exposure to international affairs community in D.C., but management leaves a lot to be desired.
pros: AC offers incredible exposure to thought leaders, practitioners, and scholars involved in international affairs, policy, and advocacy across various areas. The events are wonderful, and the people who work at the Council are curious and dedicated professionals.
cons: Your happiness at AC is deeply related to your manager, and advancement can be a slow process (especially if you do not have degrees past undergrad).

pros: Learned a lot, great team, fascinating work
cons: Few contras to mention at all.

review_title: Good exposure and networking opportunities, bad pay and junior staff is overworked
pros: good exposure and access to connections
cons: junior staff is underpaid and overworked

pros: Really committed to mission, culture of innovation, striving to really make an impact
cons: Never matches resources to ambition, severe burnout that leads to staff churn, hostile competitive environment

review_title: Great Opportunities for Junior Staff but Very Poor Work Life Balance
pros: Good opportunities for networking and some interesting events.
cons: Very poor work-life balance. Sometimes management can have unnecessarily high expectations.

pros: Top think tank in the US, great network of experts, impressive convening power. Dynamic and team-oriented environment
cons: No emphasis on work life balance

pros:
Very motivated and policy-driven group of people. The organization is relatively small, especially when compared to other think tanks or similar policy-oriented groups, but works on out-sized and robust projects. Fellow interns are typically undergrad/grad students at DC schools.
Office offers a $60/month transportation stipend for everyone, including interns. Sometimes free food from leftovers of events, etc.
Relatively interesting research projects. Some collaboration between projects/centers/initiatives, which can be exciting. Some opportunities for learning and growth, but diminished returns if you've previously worked at another think tank/policy/research organization.
Offers workshops/intern-oriented development sessions, and has a LinkedIn intern network.
Also favors from hiring internally/from intern alumni/network.
cons:
Internship is unpaid and not compensated outside of a $60/month transportation stipend.
Sometimes supervisors do not have work for you to do, or assigns work with unclear expectations or goals (aka asks for data that is extremely difficult to acquire, research task with no clear end or final goal).
There also is virtually 0 room for growth or development. Office has a great horizontal-type culture, but there is no career track, despite what may be said. Getting hired is difficult, as funding for full-time positions are far from guaranteed or expected.
Pay and opportunities for junior staff (assuming you even get hired) seems limited.

review_title: Where passionate, talented professionals burn out.
pros: A reputable, respected and influential Washington think tank that has access to the highest levels of policy making and thinking in foreign affairs.  A small organization that provides opportunities to lead and promote new ideas.  An event series that is rich and stimulating with access to speakers that are on the cutting edge of thinking on international cooperation, US foreign policy, EU policy and many new areas including Asia, Africa, Energy and Business.  Great opportunities to travel, if you are working with the right program.  Stimulating conversation with a bright staff of young, entrepreneurial professionals.
cons: Many young professionals put in two years at the Council, but begin a slow, painful period of burn out after the first couple of weeks.  Despite a strong reputation and elite network of members, partners and board directors, the Council remains a scrappy start-up with little room for professional or financial growth.  Starting salaries are not competitive and inflated titles are offered in lieu of living wages for the lower rung.  The high velocity of public and off-the-record events leaves the vast majority of staff, including program assistants and associates to do too much 'arm and leg' work while knowledge accumulated during graduate programs is left to wither on the vine.

pros: A great learning experience and exposure to the ins-&-outs of a top foreign policy thinktank
cons: Long hours; a lot of work; understaffed

review_title: A great environment to learn and develop skills, career growth opportunities limited.
pros:
Good work environment
Talented team of researchers
Exposure to fast evolving industry
cons:
Huge communication problems.
Lack of in-house career opportunities and development
Rigid pay structure
Quick employee churn rate

job_title: Health Insurance Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: flexible, regional, national, 5 day work week
cons: series placement can be hard to move from

review_title: Not a great place to be a junior.
pros: Good career mobility and can advance quite quickly.
cons: Unless you have a PhD and a career behind you you will not advance past a certain point.

review_title: Company only convenes events, is still trying to manage like it’s a small company and won’t get out if it’s own way.
pros: Smart passionate people. Lots of opportunity to meet big names in International foreign policy. Pretty good benefits.
cons: Leadership doesn’t “get it” and won’t get out of their own way....or anybody else’s. Not sustainable for the long haul. Lack of focus on priority of tactical actions leaves everyone overburdened and underpaid. Abusive executive office with an old school view on work/life balance that over manages, expects staff to always be available  and struggles to empower decision making in management . Says that talent is super important but devalues staff that are already on board, and refuses to listen to staff or provide the right structure. Executive office plays favorites, is g always logical in their thinking and throws abusive temper tantrums when angry. You will be stressed every day of your life here.

pros: Great Exposure , Dynamic Work Environment, Professional Development Opportunities, Collaborative Colleagues
cons: Frequent Long Days and Weekend Work, High Expectations

pros: Pros: many opportunities for networking
cons: Cons: we are all extremely underpaid.

review_title: Little to No Care for Junior Staff
pros: Junior staff is great. Worked here because of the people relationships not the actual work given. Was able to bring ideas to the table but had to prove each idea before it was actually implemented.
cons: They care more about the board and directors when the junior level staff are doing the work. Don't expect to make a lot of overtime, supervisors will recommend flex scheduling to even time out so your work goes unpaid. No recognition for junior staff whatsoever as they stay late night after night and then managers wonder why work is lagging. They pride themselves on events so expect to have to plan events on top of your already busy schedule. Many people are lazy and prefer to have someone else do the job for them. "think tank" but they call themselves a "do tank". If you want to work foreign policy check elsewhere. Don't expect to grow quickly, they keep junior staff in low positions for years.

review_title: Fast-paced and exciting, but need to review work-life balance.
pros: Working at the Council was a great resume booster and allowed me to gain real issue area expertise. There are some excellent people at all levels of the organization.
cons:
There's way too much bottle necking. It's next to impossible to get little things like signatures from senior management. And trying to work across programs is actively dis-incentivized thanks to an arcane and out of date funding structure.

Program assistants and unpaid interns (especially) should not be working longer hours than all of their peers, and should at least get weekends off. Work-life balance is next to non-existent.

pros: An good place to undertake an internship. You get access to influential people and events.You often get to work on serious issues. The work tends to be quite varied and interesting. The more you put in, the more you get back.
cons: You can feel undervalued as an intern. You must attend all staff meetings and town halls but no one cares about your input, and often, interns would have rather stayed at their desks to do their work.

review_title: A very positive professional development experience as a senior fellow in the International Security Program
pros: Full of pros from Dover in many subject areas.  Inside track on senior national security and international affairs decision making.  An enriching and rewarding experience that will make me a better security professional for years to come.
cons: Organization's focus at times seems fractured, trying to be too many things at once.  The organization seems to be following trendy areas and monetary endowments (understandable) but drifting away from its core missions.

review_title: Smart people, professional approach, constantly changing focus, no soul
pros: A dynamic, fast paced organization with very bright and talented people.  Impact-oriented think tank, the opposite of fuddy-duddy:  always ready to shift focus to respond to new developments.  Highly professional approach to events and publications.  Leadership good about communicating mission and approach and goals to the staff and imparting a strategic approach to all the work.
cons: Way too much turnover in the staff, including research fellows and non-research staff.  Organization often feels like it takes too much on, spreads itself too thin, and lacks focus.  Sometimes it feels like the AC lacks a soul:  it seems to lack core values and sometimes seems to bend too much to the administration in office and donor demands.

review_title: You only interact with entry-level staff. No future for full-time employment.
pros: The other interns were very intelligent and friendly.
cons:
The associate and assistant directors (entry-level positions who supervise the interns) were in a separate room, which made it hard to corroborate. For the most part they were nice but they were struggling to stay above water. 
We had no contact whatsoever with the fellows or experts that were the reason we applied for the internships.

pros: Entrepreneurial culture separates the Atlantic Council from most other D.C. think tanks. Excellent opportunity for recent grads and other entry level folks to take on a lot of responsibility and be exposed to the topmost foreign policy minds.
cons: Fulfilling the mission and getting stuff done can oftentimes take priority over the satisfaction and happiness of staff, but if you are looking to get into foreign policy and work hard for a few years, what you get out of it will far outweigh the frustration with long hours and challenging work load.

review_title: Up and coming think tank with great people and a good culture
pros:
Good culture, friendly people, interns given lots of real responsibility and guidance, lots of awesome events and cool people, exciting work that changes literally on a daily basis (there is always something happening in the world), lots of happy hours, etc.

Interns had personal sit-down with senior staff (it's a non-profit so interns keep it running in a lot of ways, but they acknowledge that and are very appreciative and giving to interns. Get free leftover food from events almost everyday!), Congressional tour for interns at end of summer
cons: Interns can sometimes have monotonous tasks/no work (but no worse than any other internship)

review_title: Enterpreneurial culture with the usual downsides
pros: This is a dynamic think tank full of smart, motivated people. There's a friendly competitive spirit among the staff that encourages high performance and collaboration. The CEO has a journalist/business background, is bottom-line oriented, and he's cultivated a very entrepreneurial atmosphere. Individuals are rewarded for their ability to add value (mostly in the form of new donor partnerships, but "thought leadership" is genuinely valued too). As in all think tanks, there's a dearth of mid-career opportunities - there tends to be wide gulf between senior managers/directors and entry-level support staff. But to its credit, the Council has tried to implement a tiered hierarchy (with research associates; assistant, associate and deputy directors) to create an upward ladder. But there's still a ceiling - unless you're coming in as a director (ex-ambassador type) anyone entering the Council should probably prepare for a 2 to 3 year experience, after which they'll want to look elsewhere for advancement. If you are energetic and positive, you're likely to find lots of opportunities to add projects and experiences to your resume, and professional networking is easy.
cons: Experiences within the Council tend to vary widely - WIDELY - depending on which program hires you. Directors essentially run their own fiefdoms and create their own mini-cultures within the broader council. The Council overall has an "all-in" culture and hours tend to be crushing. I've survived as a working mother because I have a great personal relationship with my director - but I've seen the vast majority of working moms leave in despair. The Council has no work-life balance programs (no tolerance for telecommuting or flexible schedules) and no diversity policy - an unbelievable oversight in this day and age. The lack of commitment to diversity is unfortunately very evident, not only in the way that working parents struggle to keep their jobs, but in the lack of senior women and minority employees.The organization has about 150 employees, but has only one senior woman on a "thought leadership" role (and she pre-dates the current CEO), and there are only a couple senior or semi-senior women on the ministerial/administrative side of the house.  There are only a handful of Hispanic and African American employees at any level. I'm generally very happy in my work and with the Council, but I find the lack of diversity to be genuinely discouraging.

review_title: A Few Pros but Barely Worth It
pros:
- Worked with some really great people in the junior staff and a couple of good people at higher/management levels.
- Promotions can be fairly rapid, which is somewhat meaningless but looks good on paper. Of course, once you hit a "management" level (where you're probably not managing anyone), you will no longer qualify for overtime.
- Got to do things that an entry-level employee likely does not get to do at similar organizations, particularly travel for work.
- Gained experience in areas that will be useful for future jobs, like events, logistical planning, project design, budget... and dealing with difficult people.
- Benefits are not too bad for a non-profit. Organization covers a decent amount of insurance policy costs, and vacation time isn't terrible, especially after you've worked there for over a year.
cons:
Disclaimer: Since I left, the HR department has changed a lot, so it's possible (though unlikely) that improvements have been made.

- Salaries, especially starting salaries, are hilariously low for the area. Raises are often given annually and with promotions, but are still somewhat low. Additionally, when I started there was an unofficial policy that employees not enter overtime on their time cards despite working a large amount of it. To be fair, as far as I know this policy ended a while ago, maybe after management realized that it's illegal.
- For the most part, terrible work/life balance. Junior staff is often expected to be available 24/7.
- The funding structure is decentralized, which means that the different topical centers frequently compete for the same funding and argue over who has to fund joint projects. This contributes to a lot of internal politics and grudges.
- The executive office can be both absentee and overbearing. It occasionally swoops in and demands that centers take on certain projects and change existing ones to satisfy various "partners," sometimes at no benefit to the center. Tries very hard to resist recommendations from HR.
- Despite some good experiences, the work was ultimately not very satisfying. It often felt that we just put on event after event and never accomplished anything.
- As time went on, I developed more and more moral doubts about the sources of funding across the organization. Some of them are pretty sketchy.
- I agree with a previous rater who said that you will be stressed every day of your life working here. It is unrelenting.

review_title: Generally Good Management, but Low Pay
pros: Fun international environment, got to meet Who's Who on the international scene including presidents, ambassadors and other diplomats. The good thing about coming in every day was that you didn't know who you were going to bump into that day even in the hallways.
cons: Pay was a bit low (that was then it could have improved now), unfortunately a bit too much unfriendly gossip. Very difficult to move up. Tried to move up ladder and felt discouraged by organization.

review_title: Rapidly growing, but struggling to implement change
pros:
Growth is usually good, even if it's awkward.
Interest areas are wide, and interns are encouraged to network.
New office space is open, and it's finally getting more centered.
cons:
Trying to work with other centers can be a pain.
Managing upwards happens more often than it should.
No official dress code, no employee handbook...
Hiring is very controversial; very few women in upper management despite qualifications.

pros: You get to meet interesting people in the field ... and by "meet" I mean make them coffee
cons: This place is completely dysfunctional. There is no middle management and due to a culture of over-promotion, you have people that are too young and inexperienced running the place. Expect to work overtime with no overtime pay; receive texts/email on weekends, nights & holidays; and be completely swamped+stressed every minute of every day

review_title: Good place to work starting a new career.
pros: The staff are really great, and the organization is good at finding young fun motivated people who make a good team. It is good experience for an entry level position.
cons: Poor professional development beyond entry level. Even when staff are promoted, their tasks remained the same. Regardless of title (also dependent on the program), there are really only positions for 'experts' and for 'support staff' not really a good place for someone looking for mid-level career development.

pros:
Talented people at the associate and assistant director levels.
Free coffee. 
Some interesting events.
cons:
When you are hired by the Atlantic Council, you are not just hired for one job, but for two—even three! You will be expected to perform them all perfectly, sometimes simultaneously, with a song in your heart and a smile on your lips. Because it is a privilege to be able to work hundreds of overtime hours that you will never be paid for. It is a privilege to burn out totally and completely, to watch as everyone around you does the same. You will understand that it is a privilege because you will constantly be told that it is a privilege. Over. And over again.

Do you have ideas? Do not share them! Ideas are not welcome. Can you blindly follow the status quo? Much better. Do that. And just do that. Do not forget to profusely and extensively thank your superiors for the privilege of allowing you to have this job. 

Are you a woman? Do not ever speak your mind. Women are meant to be seen and not heard at the Atlantic Council. And work three jobs with a plastered-on smile. For less $ than their male counterparts are making. Especially those with less education and degrees. 

Do you have a graduate degree? You are the perfect candidate for a low-paying job that will undoubtedly include moving furniture and stuffing envelopes. 

Any of the above not sit well with you? You will quickly be labeled a troublemaker and different rules will apply to you. But you will watch others—including your direct supervisors—produce shoddy work, miss work, miss meetings, work poorly—with no consequences.

To echo a previous poster: Run, don't walk. Work anywhere but here.

pros:
Excellent people
Solid culture
Sense of purpose to work
Ease of attending events
Good location in DC
Pick up useful skills over time
cons:
Unpaid (as intern)
Two-tier culture: static upper management, and churning pool of 20-somethings moving in and out in a 2 year cycle
Some stovepiping and over-reach

pros: mostly young, dynamic staff with international experience.  Regular hours, and program directors who are truly experts in their respective areas.
cons: lack of professional development opportunities, unequal promotions, a bit of cronyism in hiring (and promoting), inconsistent or nonexistent policies and very low salaries.

pros: Great think tank w/ a lot of important events thrown.
cons: Measly metro reimbursement, no pay that really hurts your experience. I suspect it limits the people who intern to a certain class of people.

pros:
Meet huge influencers in the field of foreign relations 
Work on important projects
Learn a lot of new skills
cons:
-Way underpaid for amount of time and work required (tons of overtime work but not overtime pay)
-have to cater to big level donors who often treat "lower" staff rudely 
-very high stress environment

pros:
- Work on varied projects
- Opportunities to participate in research, grant and proposal writing, event planning, etc. 
- Opportunities to attend events with high-level US and foreign government officials 
- They are interested in making the internship a valuable experience
cons: The internship is unpaid, and they don't always give much feedback.

review_title: Wear lots of hats, and learned a lot; but needs a management review
pros:
-Wear lots of hats and learn
-Good people in the junior ranks
cons:
-Management trickles financial stress down to junior staff
-Raises are infrequent
-Company overall flying by the seat of its pants

pros: Interesting work and events with a lot of exposure to world leaders. The staff is very friendly and accommodating to the interns and try to make the experience as beneficial as possible.
cons: Not a lot of career advancement opportunities. Shuffle intern classes in and out every semester with little chance of hiring

pros: Great camaraderie among non-director staff, opportunities to travel
cons: Terrible management of staff and finances, unethical practices, complete disconnect between the exec office with regular staff,  hiring of mid-level managers who are "superstars" but can't manage anyone or any projects, staff that brings in money will get away with just about anything, execs that behave and spend $ as if they work for a private corporation instead of a non-profit, CEO is out of touch with reality that regular staff faces, etc....

review_title: Great place the launch a career
pros: I was really positive on my time at AC. I had great bosses and found it doable to get gradual promotions . The network is fantastic and the work is super interesting.
cons: I had good bosses but not all the management there is very good. Compensation is poor and the hours are long.

review_title: a good place for entry level staff
pros:
good environment for those interested in foreign affairs
lots of responsibilities - opportunities to learn if you are a junior staff
nice coworkers
cons:
policies are still in works
lack of transparency from senior management
uneven compensation among employees
micromanagement

review_title: Excellent place to get policy experience
pros:
The leadership  rewards self-starters.
Highly entreprenurial culture
Inspiring senior leadership who are fully committed to the mission and are eager to teach and develop talent
Incredible network and access of the organization
cons:
Compensation lags the industry standard
Organizational politics are sometimes frustrating but can be managed

pros: Interesting work, many opportunities to interact with the high-level policy makers; some recent attempts to include more professional development opportunities for junior staff
cons: Promotions usually don't include change in job description; severe lack of diversity among staff; lack of professional development opportunities; high turnover in junior staff

pros: knowledgeable directors, opportunity to interact with global leaders and policymakers, new office space, free coffee, some opportunity to travel internationally.
cons: extremely low morale - people quitting in droves.  inconsistent and non-transparent criteria for salaries and promotions, especially for women.  Very poor senior management.  No professional development.

pros:
-Dynamic, smart, and relatively young workforce (for a think tank)
-Fellows were approachable and easy to work with
-No micromanagement from supervisors (in my experience)
-Interns do substantive work
-Regular professional development events
cons: -Internships are unpaid/DC cost of living

pros: Greats place to work, great connections, important work
cons: can be hard to break out of the intern bubble there unless you make a concerted effort to engage full staff

pros: Great people with lots of exposure to events with high-level officials from all over the world. AC provides great training and networking opportunities for interns.
cons: Interns are not compensated, even though some other foreign policy thinktanks pay their interns.

pros:
High profile think tank that is constantly throwing important events
Great atmosphere, very nice people
cons:
Workflow dropped off towards the end of summer as Congress goes out of session and many take vacations 
Very two tiered structure

pros: Nice colleagues, good resume booster, decent benefits package
cons: No central strategy, no organization, lots of arrogance and disconnection from the top levels of management

pros: They have positions for growth for people looking to gain more experience. Very friendly staff and great environment to be around to learn about foreign policy.
cons: I cannot think of any major cons. Low pay because it is a non-profit.

pros: It's a job. It's a place to come to work every day. It's a thing to put on your resume.
cons: Chaos, dysfunction. Absent leadership who isn't afraid to get into bed with nefarious governments in exchange for money. Google this place and "corporate donors" to see just how ugly it gets. Oh, and be prepared to work insanely long hours for measly pay. Keep your head down and don't dare to question anything...

pros: A good place to intern if you want to get experience in how a think tank is run in Washington.
cons: Not much opportunity to grow, events are not that much fun, and there is little guidance given past basic instructions.

pros: Great staff, great office. Very interesting events. Innovative staffing model
cons: interns are not utilized completely. The experience varies widely from department to department. Most of the attention goes to BSC to the detriment of other programs.

review_title: Not even if you're desperate for a job...
pros: Staff with a global perspective.  Free coffee.
cons: Non-transparent promotions, which have shown a pattern favorable to male employees.  Cronyism and more attention to style than substance.  No professional development opportunities.

pros:
Surrounded by engaged, intelligent coworkers
Interaction with successful and interesting clients/supporters
cons: Falls into a typical think tank fault of being research focused, but poor communications and ability to turn research into useful information to move the needle

review_title: Not perfect but a great overall experience
pros: Great experience to prepare you for the field.
cons: Depending on what center you're in, the interns can be left out of meetings despite the organization's self-proclaimed excellence at generating exposure for its interns

review_title: Good place to be an intern
pros:
Very high-profile network of people
High quality of events and discussions
Genuine attempt to innovate think tank usual practices
Great office environment
Opportunities to do interesting research
cons: Internships are unpaid but there is a transportation stipend

pros: Very entrepreneurial culture, nimble and leaders are eager to grow and expand reach and impact of organization.
cons: Long hours, lots of frustrated young talented staff, the organization is doing too much and not focused on core strengths.

review_title: not a bad place to work
pros: nimble fast high energy fast paced quick connections
cons: sometimes too many things happening and one loses focus

pros:
People are nice and interested in your work, they try to give you important stuff to do.
Very flexible schedules specially when interns are in school.
cons: Nothing really, It was a great experience.

pros: Dynamic atmosphere, motivated leadership and staff
cons: Sometimes too much focus on events and fundraising, less time for substantial policy work

pros: Smart people to work with - lots of intellectual stimulation
cons: needs more transparency and structure at the executive level

pros: Great office environment, opportunities for some research. Nice fellows
cons: Publishing machine, low substance opinion pieces are how you are measured. Super easy to plateau.

pros:
Opportunities to work directly with program directors
Not too much admin 
Fantastic network of scholars/practitioners
Very friendly work environment

pros: Fast moving, dynamic, respected, the opposite of a cliche sleepy insulated think tank
cons: A bit disorganized. High pressure to raise funds.

pros: Well educated and eclectic group of people to work with.
cons: The internship was unpaid but it is understandable since it is a non-profit.

pros: Open to new ideas, fast-paced, gives a lot of autonomy to junior staff
cons: disparity in salaries, unpredictable work hours, internal politics

pros: the organization host a number of interesting events
cons: The long hours made a balance of professional/personal difficult to find.

pros: Town hall meetings, lively work, great events
cons: Need to be extremely pro-active with projects

pros: great events, people, atmosphere and oppurtunities availale
cons: unpaid and expected to work 35+ hours per week

pros: Good for someone starting out or free internship, because it does give boost to the CV.
cons: Salaries are low for the regular staff, no life/work balance and no possibility to advance within the company. Management is overloading staff with work (think emails at 1 am to be answered).

pros: Large internship class and networking opportunities
cons: Disorganized HR department and need for more job clarification

cons: Work life balance could improve

cons: Heavy work load on junior employees, a lot of unnecessary paperwork

review_title: Everything that is wrong with DC
pros: Talented junior and mid level staff. Hard working people
cons: No idea where to start. Run far and fast from this place. The level of corruption is incredible.
